website_summaries.verdict: A great choice if you want a small novelty throw or gift pillow with a cute design.
pros: A cute option that is praised for its adorable design and comfortable cushioning
Consumers report it works well on the ends of couches, on smaller chairs, or for back support
cons: The small size left a few users disappointed

customer_reviews.title: The pillow itself is adorable and she really liked it
customer_reviews.text: Got this for my sisters birthday. She has a dachshund pup. The pillow itself is adorable and she really liked it. With that said, this item is very small and if one is expecting to use this as a pillow, you'd better have a tiny head. Otherwise it really is for displaying only.
customer_reviews.author: melhels

customer_reviews.title: Cute pillow, but pay attention to the size listed!
customer_reviews.text: The pillow itself is very cute and well made... but it is much smaller than I anticipated-- even though the listed dimensions are accurate, I should have paid more attention to the actual size of the pillow.
customer_reviews.author: Tina Collins

customer_reviews.title: Cute pillow.
customer_reviews.text: The pillow is quite cute... it doesn’t really have a pillowy use because it is quite small. It’s a nice decoration. I purchased it for my mom who has a dachshund.

customer_reviews.title: good

customer_reviews.title: Very small, overpriced, but super cute.
customer_reviews.text: Very cute, well made. I must not have paid attention to the measurements listed for the size of this pillow. It is VERY small. Not useful for much. Kinda looks silly even as a decorative throw pillow as it is so small. Overpriced for what it is. I will keep it because it is so cute and I love anything Doxie.

customer_reviews.title: Love it!!!
customer_reviews.text: This little pillow is perfect. Yes, it is small, but that is clearly stated in the description. The design is woven in, tapestry type fabric. Not printed. The back is black. I bought two of these, and thinking about ordering more as gifts. These will be great for lumbar support. I take a small pillow when I fly because plane seats are so uncomfortable, but I might get one to keep in the car also. One, however, is for the guest room bed. So adorable!
customer_reviews.author: Joyce M.

customer_reviews.title: Beautiful and Very Sentimental
customer_reviews.text: This pillow was one of my gifts to my mother. This pillow is so awesome. It’s endearing, it’s flattering in the home and my mom loves it. I bought two in case someone else might like it. Someone did, they saw it in our home and they really liked it so, I gave the other one to her. It’s very quaint and seemingly very well made. I say seemingly because we haven’t had it long. If anything changes I will certainly update my review.

product_meta.title: Manual 12.5 x 8.5-Inch Decorative Embroidered Word Pillow, It's Been a Long Day
product_meta.description: Style:It's Been a Long DayAlthough Thomas Lemuel Oates started Manual Woodworkers and Weavers in 1932, the story goes back further. The roots of the company can be found in Oates' entrepreneurial spirit. He and his brother used to farm the mountain areas of Bat Cave in western North Carolina. They would also help their mother find materials for her crafts. The sons began to make wooden whistles, buckets and bird-houses. They would sell their wares along with her crafts to the people from Charlotte that came through in their horse-drawn buggies on the way to the mountains. Later, Thomas worked at the Ashville Postcard Company. When the Depression hit, he lost his job, but it inspired him to go into business and sell crafts, like cornhusk dolls and woven pieces, that were produced by the local women. He had learned about the wholesale business while working at Ashville. He built a waterwheel to generate electricity at a mill, began making product and opened shop. Over the years, he expanded the company. His son, Lemuel Oates, who would next manage the company, says he worked in the business from a young age. He explains the products were made from cotton scraps left over from making socks. Half-inch circles would be looped together to form a variety of products. Lemuel Oates went to college and then settled in Richmond. In December 1973, he returned to Bat Cave and took over the company. In 2007 his son Travis and his daughter, Molly Oates Sherrill, took over the business.
feature_bullets: Features dog design and reads It's been a LONG day
Check out manual woodworkers and weavers extensive line of home decor, tapestries, wall plaques and hangings, women's fashion accessories and bags
